metadata.title: Green synthesis of spongy Nano-ZnO productive of hydroxyl radicals for unconventional solar-driven photocatalytic remediation of antibiotic enriched wastewater

sections.text:
Journal of Environmental Management 271 (2020) 110961
Available online 30 June 2020 0301-4797/© 2020 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Research article
Green synthesis of spongy Nano-ZnO productive of hydroxyl radicals for unconventional solar-driven photocatalytic remediation of antibiotic enriched wastewater
Amr A. Essawy a,b,*, Ibrahim Hotan Alsohaimi a,**, Mosaed S. Alhumaimess a, Hassan M. A. Hassan a,c, Mahmoud M. Kamel a
a Chemistry Department, College of Science, Jouf University, Sakaka, P.O. Box 2014, Saudi Arabia b Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Fayoum University, 63514, Fayoum, Egypt c Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Suez University, Suez, Egypt
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Green synthesis ZnO defective Nanoparticles Hydroxyl radicals Solar-illumination Antibiotic wastewater remediation Flumequine photocatalytic degradation
A B S T R A C T
Herein, novel green/facile approach to synthesize spongy defective zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnONPs) is presented using for the first time pomegranate seeds molasses as a green capping fuel/reducing mediator during an aqueous solution combustion process. The developed ZnONPs is characterized by UV–Vis. Spectrophotometry and fluorimetry, XRD, Raman spectroscopy, SEM, TEM and BET. Interestingly, pomegranate seeds molasses within a viable content of bio-capping molecules reveal a defective nanoporous ZnO NPs of smaller particle size, greater pore size/volume, and higher surface area compared to the bulky non-biogenic ZnONPs. Moreover, the biosynthesized defective ZnONPs showed narrowed band gap and higher absorption of visible photons that breed higher density of hydroxyl radicals (�OH) under Solar-illumination. Even further, the bulk ZnO and the biosynthesized ZnO photocatalysts were examined in photodegrading flumequine (FL) antibiotic. The bulk ZnO gives 41.46% photodegradation efficiency compared to 97.6% for the biosynthesized ZnO. In highly acidic or highly alkaline media, FL photodegradability is greatly retarded. Scavenging experiment infers considerable contribution of holes over electrons in photodegradation reaction. The biosynthesized ZnO shows high durability in FL photodegradation after four reusing cycles. These promising findings highlight new insights for biogenic synthesis of tuned size/controlled morphology semiconductor NPs relevant to environmental remediation applications.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Due to continuous exploration of new characteristics within promising diverse applications, nanotechnology has been capturing more and more attention, especially in dealing with semiconductor materials for several decades. High-surface-to-volume semiconductor nanoparticles and other exceptional physicochemical characteristics make them a leading contender in materials that have been renovated.
Zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles were described among the various semiconductors as functionally promising and versatile inorganic materials with unparalleled optical and electrical properties that can be adjusted by modifying the size and morphology (Ma et al., 2019). Accordingly, ZnO displays a wide variety of appealing applications in
the optoelectronics, piezoelectrical devices, transparent electronics, chemical sensors (Saito et al., 2018; Zou et al., 2018; Li et al., 2018), environmental protection, pharmaceutical, cosmetic, agricultural and food industries (Espitia et al., 2012). In addition, ZnO NPs demonstrated tremendous efficacy in biological and medical areas such as biological labeling, bio-sensing, gene delivery, drug delivery, nanomedicine and cosmetic sectors owing to their anti-microbial, anti-diabetic and wound healing capabilities (Dastjerdi and Montazer, 2010; Radzimska and Jesionowski, 2014; Mishra et al., 2017; Moezzi et al., 2012). ZnO nanoparticles have a wurtzite structure and belong to the family of semiconductors category II-IV, which has a covalence between ionic and covalent semiconductors (Ngoepe et al., 2018). Moreover, advanced oxidation process (AOPs) and the field of photocatalysis utilize ZnO to
* Corresponding author. Chemistry Department, College of Science, Jouf University, Sakaka, P.O. Box 2014, Saudi Arabia. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: aae01@fayoum.edu.eg (A.A. Essawy), ehalshaimi@ju.edu.sa (I.H. Alsohaimi).
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Environmental Management
journal homepage: http://www.elsevier.com/locate/jenvman
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvman.2020.110961 Received 10 February 2020; Received in revised form 17 May 2020; Accepted 12 June 2020
Journal of Environmental Management 271 (2020) 110961
aid in remediating environment from hazardous contaminants more efficiently compared to conventional methods. Recently, wide utilization of antibiotics to confront infectious diseases and maintain the body health for human, fauna and flora (Kummerer, 2009) could be accompanied by abusing or inconvenient disposal. The antimicrobial agent, flumequine (FL), is one of the fluoroquinolone antiobiotics (Fig. 1) frequently detected within 6.9 μg/g in soil and 2.5–50 ng/L in aquatic media (Rodrigues-Silva et al., 2013; Feng et al., 2015a, 2015b). Unfortunately, the presence of trace amounts of FL in environment may result in resistive microbes and distressed organisms. Therefore, its presence in the aquatic life exhibits serious environmental issues that pave the way to an inevitable need for its save and efficient removal.
To attain highly effaceable ZnO-photocatalyzed processes, it is important to devote research for morphology evolution to material characteristics. Thereby, tremendous attempts have been produced with distinct morphologies in ZnO’s preparation techniques. Methods employing physical, chemical and green synthetic routes have been successfully presented. In recent years, researchers are remarkably interested in achieving advancement in the green technicalities for synthesizing semiconductor nanoparticles. This is due to advantages of safety, rapidity, positive economic and eco-friendly large scale productivity as compared with physical and chemical approaches Joseph and Mathew (2015); Kaushal et al. (2016). In such fascinating area of green biosynthesis of nanoparticles, microorganisms, enzymes, alga and plant extracts are used. The plant extracts contain various types of phenolic and flavonoid compounds that help in nanoparticles formation (Khan et al., 2016; Tahir et al., 2016). For example, from the extracts of various plants (Jafarirad et al., 2016; Ngoepe et al., 2018; Haritha et al., 2016; Kalaiselvi et al., 2015; Essawy, 2018; Kumar et al., 2015; Elango et al., 2016), ZnO and other nanomaterials were synthesized.
In the field of photocatalysis, ZnO is a wide band gap semiconductor with a band gap of 3.37 eV that unfortunately displays a lower compatibility to utilize solar energy (Essawy et al., 2018). In 2011, in Science, Chen et al. reported on a technique to reduce the band gap of TiO2 semiconductor materials that opened the door for scientists to a new globe (Chen et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2017; Essawy et al., 2017). In fabricating solar-responsive ZnO NPs with high performance, factors of porosity and surface oxygen defects are greatly crucial in exploring merits of ZnO in photocatalysis. The porous structure could exhibit higher adsorption potentiality, and the oxygen vacancies act as capture centers for photogenerated electrons. Accordingly, the reassemble of photogenerated electron-hole pairs is prohibited and more electrons reach the surface producing high density of reactive oxidizing species (Khan et al., 2014; Zhang et al., 2016). Furthermore, a defect level will be generated plausibly narrowing the band gap and enhances the electrical properties (Xu et al., 2015).
The recent bio-inspired green synthetic routes offer a uniquely flexible growth of nanoparticles of controlled shape and size (Narayanan and Sakthivel, 2010; Thakkar et al., 2010; Katata-Seru et al., 2018).
Herein, the pomegranate seeds extract is presented as biogenic reducing and capping fuel during a novel one pot aqueous solution combustion reaction for the fabrication of a nanoporous defective ZnO nanoparticles. The amount of pomegranate extract added to the reaction course confers an interesting structural features of the prepared ZnO enabling highly efficient harvesting of solar energy. Furthermore, stunning Solar-sensitization for extensive productivity of reactive oxidizing species urgently required for a potent confronting of aquatic toxification by FL. To date, ZnO-photocatalyzed degradation of FL wastewater is markedly delimited in literature. Even further, to the best of our knowledge, the Solar-driven photocatalytic degradation of FL wastewater has not been reported.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: A fresh pomegranate fruits were supplied from local market in Aljouf region, City of Sakaka, Saudi Arabia. Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn (NO3)2.6H2O) of analytical grade, ethanol, terephthalic acid, zinc oxide, sodium hydroxide and Flumequine were obtained from Sigma Aldrich. The physico-chemical characteristics of flumequine are listed in Table 1 (Sotelo et al., 2013; Santoke et al., 2009). Deionized (DI) water was performed to prepare all the working aqueous solutions.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Preparation of pomegranate seeds extract (PMSE)
sections.text: Fresh Pomegranate fruits have been rinsed with tap water several times, then deionized water to remove dust particles. After that the pomegranate fruits were peeled and seeds were collected, washed with DI water. Pomegranate seeds (200 g) were placed in glass beaker and allowed to be soaked in 500 mL of ethanol for five days in refrigerator. The watery color of ethanol becomes deep rose while the seeds were bleached indicating the extraction of colored biogenic active ingredient in the seeds. The solution was filtered to separate any sediments then subjecting to rotary evaporator at 50 �C till reaching a highly viscous PMSE. The extract was stored in dark and at room temperature to be used in the desired biosynthesis process.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Biogenic synthesis of zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnO NPs)
sections.text:
In one pot reaction mixture, different weights of PMSE (100, 200, 300, 400 mg) are placed in four identical dried and cleaned crucibles
A.A. Essawy et al.
Journal of Environmental Management 271 (2020) 110961
(�50 mL capacity), then exactly 30.0 mL of DI water was added to dissolve the extract. After complete dissolution of extract, constant weight of Zn(NO3)2.6H2O (1.0 g) were added to each crucible, stirred till complete dissolution. A slight darkness of the rose color of PMSE solution was noticed by adding the zinc nitrate salt indicating an interaction attribute between solution of PMSE and aqueous Zn2þ ions. Additionally, a fifth crucible contains the same contents above except the PMSE is prepared to get bulk ZnO particles as a control sample denoted by 0MSCBZnO, (MSCB ¼ Mediator Solution Combustion Bulk). All the prepared crucibles are placed in muffle furnace preheated to 425 �C starting a solution combustion reaction for 2 h. At the end of combustion process, ZnO particles is formed as shown in Fig. 2. As seen, an interesting spongy and ashy like texture of the synthesized ZnO particles is formed as the mass of PMSE added to the reaction course increases. The samples of ZnO prepared in presence of 100, 200, 300, 400 mg of PMSE were denoted as 1MSCDZnO, 2MSCDZnO, 3MSCDZnO and 4MSCDZnO, respectively. (MSCD ¼ Mediator Solution Combustion Defective).

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Spectrofluorimetric assessment of solar-driven �OH radicals produced from biosynthesized ZnO NPs
sections.text: The performance of the developed biogenic synthesized ZnO NPs in producing the reactive oxidizing species, hydroxyl radicals (�OH) under solar irradiation were monitored using the photoluminescence (PL) technique (Essawy et al., 2016). In a typical procedure, 20.0 mg of the developed materials (0MSCBZnO, 1MSCDZNO, 2MSCDZnO, 3MSCDZnO or 4MSCDZnO) was added to 50 mL mixture of terephthalic acid, TA (5 � 10 3 mol L 1) and NaOH (1 � 10 2 mol L 1) and subjected to solar irradiation of 3.9 � 104 Lux (measured by PeakTech® digital multi tester). Nearly 5 mL of mixed solution is removed and centrifuged at a given illumination time, where the efficiency in the productivity of �OH radicals is evaluated by monitoring the characteristic fluorescent signal of the formed hydroxy terephthalic fluorophore (λem 426 nm) at λex ¼ 315 nm.

sections.heading: 2.2.4. Photocatalytic experiments
sections.text:
The photocatalytic efficiency of the developed biogenic synthesized ZnO NPs was evaluated by monitoring the degradation of FL antibiotic in aqueous solution. The working solution of 50 mL contains [FL] of 15 mg/L chosen to be relatively higher than the previously degraded in other literatures and 10 mg of the studied photocatalysts that is also chosen to be either similar to or lower than that tested in literatures (Vaizogullar, 2017, 2018; Gul et al., 2019; Zeng et al., 2019; Kamagate et al., 2018; Iqbal et al., 2020). The mixture were subjected to 5 min of ultrasonication then stirring for 30 min In dark to attain adsorption equilibria of FL to the surface of catalyst. Thereafter, it is subjected to solar irradiation of 37 � 103 Lux. At a working time of illumination, � 5 mL of the working solution is withdrawn and centrifuged to remove the suspended catalysts nanoparticles giving a FL clear solution. After that, in the clear solution, the FL residue is quantified spectrophotometrically where the efficacy of FL photodegradation is addressed by monitoring the absorbance of FL at the peak assigned at λmax 330 nm (Harrabi et al.,
2018; Vaizogullar, 2017; Vaizogullar, 2018; Vaizogullar, 2020). Meanwhile, the direct photolysis of FL without catalyst and in presence of the bulk ZnO (0MSCBZnO) and commercial ZnO catalysts were employed at the same irradiation conditions as a control experiments for aid of comparison. Further examination of FL photodegradability was followed in different pH sets (3.5, 6.6, natural 8.7, and 11.0). These pH sets were chosen to be lower than, close to, and higher than the FL pKa of 6.5. Adjusting pH of the working solution was employed using proper volume of HCl and NaOH (0.1 M). Moreover, reusability study was employed under the aforementioned optimized conditions where the used ZnO NPs after completion of photodegradation cycle was collected, washed with deionized water and then dried in order to be renovated for the subsequent photodegradation run.

sections.heading: 2.3. Instruments
sections.text:
TGA-51 Shimadzu thermogravimetric analyzer was used to perform the thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA). Using the Agilent Cary 60 spectrophotometer, UV–visible absorption spectra were registered. A Shimadzu IR Tracer-100 Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrophotometer was used to record FTIR readings. Powder XRD readings have been recorded using the X-ray diffractometer Maxima – X (D/Max2500VB2þ/ Pc, Shimadzu Company, Japan) with an X-ray wavelength Cu detector. Sample TEM images were taken using electron microscopy scanning (JEOL, JEM-2100, Japan). Using the HOUND UNCHAINED LABS spectrometer, Raman spectroscopic analysis was conducted. The morphological features of the developed materials were investigated using field
A.A. Essawy et al.
Journal of Environmental Management 271 (2020) 110961
emission scanning electron microscopy (Zeiss FESEM Ultra 60). A NOVA 4200e (Quantachrome Instruments) Surface Area & Pore Size Analyzer collected the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K. To estimate the specific surface area, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation was used. Pore size distributions were evaluated using the isothermic adsorption branch Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) technique. UV–Vis. Measurements of photoluminescence on the Agilent fluorescence spectrophotometer were reported.

sections.heading: 3.1. X- ray diffraction, XRD
sections.text:
The XRD patterns of the 0MSCBZnO and the different biosynthesized 1MSCDZnO, 2MSCDZnO, 3MSCDZnO and 4MSCDZnO NPs are shown in Fig. 3. The diffraction pattern (a) corresponds to 0MSCBZnO confirms the formation of pure ZnO of hexagonal wurtzite structure (JCPDS No. 36–1451) where the features peaks at 2θ ¼ 31.6�, 34.4�, 36.2�, 47.4�, 56.6�, 62.9�, 66.4�, 67.8�, 69.0�, 72.6� and 77.0� can be attributed to the corresponding crystal surfaces of the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103), (200), (112), (201), (004) and (202) faces, respectively (Harish et al., 2017). The XRD patterns of greenly synthesized ZnO NPs (b – e) show some interesting features represented in decrease in both crystallinity, peak intensity and also a noticeable peaks’ shifting to smaller 2θ values. Moreover, two additional diffraction peaks of low intensity are appeared clearly at 2θ ¼ 44.4 and 64.4� in samples 2MSCDZnO, 3MSCDZnO and 4MSCDZnO. This highly observes the existence of some defective distortion of the lattice owing potentially to the creation of oxygen vacancies and similar increase in the distance between the crystalline plates (Darvishi et al., 2019).
The average size of the crystallite is estimated using the DebyeScherrer equation:

sections.heading: D ¼ K λ/β cosθ (1)
sections.text: where D is the size of the crystallite (nm), k is the Scherrer’s constant of value 0.89, λ is the wavelength of the X-ray (λ ¼ 1.54056 Å), β is full width at half maximum (in radian) of the peak under estimation and θ is Bragg’s angle (in degrees). Accordingly, estimates of average crystallite sizes for 0MSCBZnO, 1MSCDZnO, 2MSCDZnO, 3MSCDZnO and 4MSCDZnO are respectively, 17.83, 16.14, 13.01, 12.87 and 12.49 nm.

sections.heading: 3.2. Raman spectroscopy
sections.text:
Fig. 4 illustrates the Raman spectra of the biosynthesized defective
ZnO NPs (3MSCDZnO), (spectrum b) in comparison with the purely synthesized bulk one (0MSCBZnO), (spectrum a). As shown, 0MSCBZnO sample reveals several Raman peaks located at 390.8, 437.8 and 573.1 cm 1 primarily owing to the vibrations of oxygen. Otherwise, the corresponding peak areas for 3MSCDZnO are markedly weakened and their positions are shifted to lower wavenumbers. These findings further imply a role of oxygen vacancies and the subsequent intrinsic defective structure in decreasing the vibrational frequency associated with oxygen atom (Xu et al., 2020). Furthermore, the assigned red shifting could be originated from mass fluctuations and a possible reduction of the average atomic mass at the oxygen atoms due the ascribed oxygen defects (Ansari et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 3.3. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA)
sections.text: Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted to address the thermal stability of the developed bulk and biosynthesized defective ZnO NPs. Fig. 5 shows the TGA thermogram of 0MSCBZnO and 4MSCDZnO NPs. Results indicate a high thermal stability and insignificant weight loss for the bulk sample 0MSCBZnO up to 500 �C while the biosynthesized 4MSCDZnO sample shows a weight loss of about 4.6% at � 298 �C. This can be related to thermal degrading of residual phenolics and flavonoides biomolecules involved during the biosynthetic route. However, subsequent incremental temperature did not result to considerable weight loss indicating high thermal stability.

sections.heading: 3.4. Morphological implementation by FESEM and TEM analyses
sections.text:
The morphological features of the as-prepared ZnO NPs were concluded using FESEM and TEM. As shown in Fig. 6A, the sample 0MSCBZnO exhibits the characteristic hexagonal wurtzite facet topographically assembled to form bulk crystals. Image of higher magnification (Fig. 6B) shows interlaced clusters further confirm the bulky structure. Fig. 6C depicts the FESEM imagery of the biosynthesized ZnO NPs (2MSCDZnO) where the morphological topography illustrates a nanospheres efficiently distributed without agglomeration meanwhile some defective positions can be seen.
Further morphological exploration of the bulk 0MSCBZnO and biosynthesized defective 3MSCDZnO NPs was employed using the TEM imaging as illustrated in Fig. 7. The bulky appearance for the sample 0MSCBZnO is shown in Fig. 7A while the TEM image of 3MSCDZnO sample shows mostly spherical/hemispherical morphology in addition to some hexagonal and square shapes with particle sizes ranges from 6.3 to 26.4 nm. From the consistent findings of FESEM and TEM, it is evident that the developed aqueous solution combustion technique reveals in
A.A. Essawy et al.
Journal of Environmental Management 271 (2020) 110961
presence of the biogenic mediated reducing and capping PMSE reagent an interesting surface defective nanoparticulate morphology. Unlike, the free biogenic mediated route results in a bulky assemblage morphology most probably undesirable in case of surface active correlated applications.

sections.heading: 3.5. UV–vis. Spectroscopy and band gab calculations
sections.text:
The fabrication of ZnO NPs could be confirmed by monitoring the UV–vis electronic spectroscopy as the wavelength corresponds to
A.A. Essawy et al.
Journal of Environmental Management 271 (2020) 110961
surface Plasmon resonance (SPR) could be addressed. The UV–vis spectra for 0MSCBZnO and 2MSCDZnO samples that is recorded in Fig. 8A show excitonic peaks of absorption around 370–386 nm. Due to the inherent band gap, the distinctive absorption peak of ZnO can be identified as excited electrons traveling from their valence band to the conductive band (O2p ⇒ Zn3d) (Darroudi et al., 2013). Based on Fig. 8A, the absorption of 2MSCDZnO is red shifted compared to that of 0MSCBZnO with a considerable increase in absorbing visible photons. This once again could be rendered to the surface defects oxygen vacancies.
Otherwise, Fig. 8A and B, show the plotting of Kubelka-Munk function (Eq. (2)) to estimate the band gap of the purely bulk ZnO NPs (0MSCBZnO) and the biosynthesized defective ZnO NPs (2MSCDZnO).
(αhν) ¼ A (hv – Eg)1/2 (2)
Where α is the coefficient of extinction, h is the constant of Planck, v is the frequency of vibration, A is the constant of absorption, and Eg is the gap in eV. The Eg values estimated for 0MSCBZnO and 2MSCDZnO are 3.21 eV and 3.07 eV, respectively, from the linear extrapolation of (αhν)1/2 versus (hν).

sections.heading: 3.6. BET surface analysis
sections.text: In order to get in deep addressing for the role of pomegranate seeds extract in controlling the structural and surfacial features of the developed materials, analyses of N2 adsorption-desorption, pore volume and pore size were performed. Table 2 lists the values of surface area, pore size and pore volume along with the average particle size on XRD basis for the different samples prepared via the developed biogenic avenue in comparison with control sample prepared without addition of pomegranate seeds extract. As shown, all samples can be seen as nanoporous structures. Interestingly, a notable influence of the amount added from pomegranate mediator on the structural parameters is indicated. In comparing results, addition of pomegranate seeds extract could results in 10 times increase in surface area, 2 times increase in pore size and 7 times increase in pore volume. Accordingly, the unique cellular structure offered by addition of pomegranate seeds extract is expected to save wide range of reactive sites with plausible space. This in addition to the enhancement found in visible light absorption enables higher productivity of reactive oxidizing species when subjecting the greenly developed samples to solar irradiation.

sections.heading: 3.7. Photoluminescence spectroscopic analysis
sections.text:
Photoluminescene (PL) spectroscopy is a viable tool that gives first insight regarding the photoactivity of semiconductor NPs. It is importantly comprehend some crucial points in assessing the consequent influences upon photons absorption by a semiconductor NPs starting from the destiny of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, effectiveness of trapping charge carriers to the migration of semiconductor NPs. The PL intensity for semiconductor NPs are correlated to the recombination rate of photogenerated charge carriers. As illustrated in Fig. 9, both the nonbiosynthesized bulk ZnO NPs (spectrum a) and those biosynthesized defective ZnO NPs (spectra b-d) show a distinctive similar curve-shaped
A.A. Essawy et al.
Journal of Environmental Management 271 (2020) 110961
PL spectra with noticeable red shift from 386 nm for 0MSCBZnO to 393 nm for 3MSCDZnO. The 0MSCBZnO emission spectrum shows two bands, the first band is stated at 386 nm owing to free excitonic bandedge UV emission, which appears to be more intense and sharper. The second band appears wide occupying the region from 415 nm to 460 nm referring to the charge carrier’s deactivation due to oxygen vacancies and defect state transition (Jiang et al., 2007). Moreover, by comparing the exciton PL intensity due to 0MSCBZnO with that related to the biosynthesized defective ZnO NPs, there is remarkable quenching of PL peaks of the latter than the first. These results are illustrative to an enhanced separation between the photogenerated charge carriers, and a prohibiting of their recombination, therefore increasing the potentiality in producing hydroxyl radicals (�OH) oxidizing species (Lv et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 3.8. Photoluminescence (PL) monitoring of hydroxyl radicals (�OH) productivity
sections.text:
In dealing with the increased levels of environmental pollution, developing a green and sustainable confrontation technicalities is always inevitably required. Regarding that important issue, the asprepared ZnO NPs in absence of biogenic mediator (0MSCBZnO) and presence of different amounts of the biogenic mediator, “PMSE” (1MSCDZnO, 2MSCDZnO, 3MSCDZnO and 4MSCDZnO) were examined for its efficacy to produce hydroxyl radicals (�OH) under solar illumination. Within the frame of semiconductor photo-illuminated system, hydroxyl radicals (�OH) remains the mostly active oxidizing species commonly known in photodegrading pollutants. Here, the extremely sensitive photoluminescence (PL) labeling of �OH radicals’ productivity was employed using the probe terephthalic acid (TA) (Essawy et al., 2016). In an alkaline medium (NaOH), �OH radicals interact with TA producing a hydroxy-TA fluorophore of characteristic fluorescent signal at � 426 nm. The higher the fluorescence intensity recorded, the higher the concentration of �OH radicals (Xu et al., 2020). Figures (10A and B) show respectively, the recorded fluorescence spectra upon temporal Solar illumination (till 40 min) for an alkaline solution contains constant amounts of TA and the as-prepared 0MSCBZnO or 4MSCDZnO NPs. As seen, the maximum depicted fluorescence intensity for the hydroxylated-TA due to the biosynthesized sample (4MSCDZnO) is nearly 10 times higher than that collected due to the bulky sample (0MSCBZnO). This strongly indicates the higher productivity of �OH radicals oxidative species upon solar irradiating of the biosynthesized defective ZnO NPs compared to the bulky ones. Moreover, enlarged comparison between the as-prepared ZnO NPs in producing �OH radicals is illustrated in Fig. 10C. Generally, the biosynthesized ZnO samples are
A.A. Essawy et al.
Journal of Environmental Management 271 (2020) 110961
better than the bulky ZnO NPs in producing �OH radicals, therefore exhibiting better efficiency when engaged in photodegrading hazmat. More interestingly, increasing the amount of PMSE added to the biogenic synthetic route results in ZnO NPs of improved potentiality in producing �OH radicals.
Contemplation in the aforementioned results concluded from XRD, UV–vis. Spectrophotometry/fluorometry, BET, SEM and TEM analyses behold for the following: (i) The developed biogenic synthetic route yields a defective nanoporous ZnO NPs of smaller particle size, greater pore size, and higher surface area that are highly responsive to visible photons; (ii) The estimated reduction in band gap most probably owing to the presence of oxygen vacancies defect sites; (iii) The referred oxygen vacancies defect states viably trap and migrate the photogenerated charge carriers prohibiting their recombination; (iv) Subsequently, higher productivity of the mostly active oxidative species �OH radicals is monitored and giving the opportunity for efficient performance when involved in photodegrading environmental hazardous under solar illumination.

sections.heading: 3.9. Spectroscopic monitoring of photodegradation
sections.text:
As concluded from the illustrative results of �OH productivity in the previous section 3.8, the sample 4MSCDZnO was chosen with the bulk ZnO to evaluate the photocatalytic degradation efficacy in degrading the antibiotic flumequine (FL) as a model environmental contaminate. FL exhibits two characteristic absorption peaks at 247 nm and 330 nm. The following Eq. (3) was applied to calculate the degradation efficiency:
E%¼ A0 At
A0  x  100 (3)
where A0 is the FL maximum absorbance at the fixed wavelength at zero time of solar irradiation while At is the recorded absorbance at time of irradiation (t).
As recorded in Fig. 11, the absorbance of FL was sequentially decreased with increasing the irradiation time. When using bulk ZnO as photocatalyst, a relatively weak decrease in FL absorption spectrum (Fig. 11A) corresponding to 41.46% photodegradation efficiency is reached while using the defective ZnO (4MSCDZnO) results in almost complete disappearance of the FL absorption profile (Fig. 11B) with a
A.A. Essawy et al.
Journal of Environmental Management 271 (2020) 110961
degradation efficiency of 97.6%. Fig. 12A discloses the contribution of adsorption in removing FL along 30 min of adsorption equilibrium. As seen, after 30 min of FL adsorption in dark, a decrease by 2–3% in FL concentration is accomplished for contacting FL with the different catalyst surfaces. Moreover, the degradation kinetics illustrated in Fig. 12B obeys first order and compares the photodegradation of FL in absence of photocatalyst, in presence of bulk ZnO or defective ZnO (4MSCDZnO) as well as commercial ZnO. The results summarized in Table 3 show high photostability of FL towards direct photolysis with a very low photodegradability rate constant, k ¼ 0.0016 min 1. Also, the results address the superior photocatalytic activity of the defective ZnO (4MSCDZnO) with k ¼ 0.0397 min 1 over bulk ZnO with k ¼ 0.0055 min 1 or commercial ZnO giving k of 0.0231 min 1. Accordingly, the biogenic defective ZnO photocatalyst achieves either 7.22 folds or 1.72 folds enhancement in FL degradation over the non-biogenic bulk ZnO or commercial ZnO, respectively. Additionally the decrease of pH at the end of degradation process from the corresponding initial value refers to the acid nature of the degraded products. The surpass of the defective ZnO NPs over the bulk ZnO in the photocatalyzed degradation of FL contaminant as revealed from the aforesaid results have been found harmonious and proven those complemented from BET surface area characterization, Raman spectra, band gap narrowing, inferred charge carrier separation form PL monitoring, to the extensive productivity of �OH oxidizing species. Furthermore, Table 4 demonstrates the surpass of the developed biogenic defective ZnO NPs over others reported in literatures. As seen, the optimized conditions in using the developed biosynthesized ZnO reveals 97.6% of FL photocatalytic degradation with rate constant 0.0397 min 1. This rate constant is found to be superior by � 4 folds when using LaMgO in degrading FL (10 mg) under UV illumination (Vaizogullar, 2018), �5 folds when using ZnO/TiO2/Sepiolite (Vaizogullar, 2017), �1.7 folds when using B/N codoped TiO2 (Zeng et al., 2019), �2.2 folds when using Goethite/hematite/H2O2 (Kamagate et al., 2018), �1.98 folds when using CeO2 (Iqbal et al., 2020). Furthermore, attaining this surpass in FL photocatalytic degradation under Solar-illumination as a renewable, safe and cost effective illumination source added an interesting advantage for the developed biosynthesized ZnO NPs.

sections.heading: 3.10. Influence of pH on the photodegradation process
sections.text:
A significant influence on the efficacy of photocatalyzed degradation is attributed to the working pH. Changing pH could exhibits various effects on the chemistry of both the target pollutant and the applied photocatalyst due to a subsequent change in their charge as well as the redox potential of the produced reactive species (Shah et al., 2018; Chekuri, and Tirukkovalluri, 2017). For a constant amount of photocatalyst and fixed concentration of FL, the photocatalytic degradation of FL was studied in four working pH values (3.5, 6.6, natural 8.7, and 11). Since the pKa of FL is 6.5 denoted as “HA”, hence the applied acidic medium reveals cationic form (H2Aþ) while the working alkaline one results in the anionic form “A “, meanwhile the examined ZnO defective NPs being a positively charged at the acidic pH 3.5 and negatively charged at the working alkaline pH 11.0. (Feng et al., 2015a,b).
As illustrated in Fig. 13A, the decrease in FL absorbance while employing photodegradation reaction in pH 3.5 results in 54.7% removal efficiency of FL. While working at pH 6.6 that is close to the FL pKa reveals FL removal within efficiency 85.6% (Fig. 13B). On the other hand following the photocatalyzed degradation of FL at pH 11.0 reveals FL removal efficiency by 34% (Fig. 13C). In aqueous solution of natural pH 8.7, the maximum photodegradation efficiency of FL was reached and give value of 97.6%. Moreover, the photodegradation kinetics shown in Fig. 13(D and E) compares the degradation rates of FL at the four working pH values (3.5, 6.6, natural 8.7, and 11). Measuring the pH at the end of degradation course reveals the decrease of pH 3.5 to 3.41, pH 6.6 to 6.36, and the pH 11.0 to 10.83. As previously estimated, when conducting the photocatalytic degradation reaction at the aqueous solution of natural slightly alkaline pH 8.7, the maximum rate constant and t1/2 of values 0.0397 min 1 and 17.45 min are obtained. Otherwise, the rate constants obtained at pH 3.5 and 11.0 are greatly decreased to 0.009 and 0.005 min 1, respectively. This remarkable retardation in the degradation rate could be attributed to the electrostatic repulsion between the positively charged FL molecules and the positive surface of the photocatalyst ZnO at the highly acidic pH. Furthermore, at highly alkaline pH, the negative charges carried by FL molecules and ZnO photocatalyst results in an electrostatic repulsion, thereby the least contact of FL antibiotic pollutant and ZnO surface that led to the least photodegradation rate. These aforementioned repulsive electrostatic interactions and their retarding influence on the FL degradation are further confirmed by employing FL photodegradation at pH 6.6 that is close to the FL pKa. At this pH, the electrostatic repulsions are decreased leading to better contact between FL molecules and ZnO catalyst that results in improved rate of FL photodegradation within a rate constant of 0.0239 min 1 (Fig. 13E). Additionally, the extensive amount of OH ions causes possible scavenging of �OH according to Eq. (4) (Sayed et al., 2017).
�OH þ OH → O� – þ H2O (k ¼ 61.2 � 1010 M 1s 1, at alkaline pH) (4)
On contrary, the slight alkaline pH addressed for the aqueous
A.A. Essawy et al.
Journal of Environmental Management 271 (2020) 110961
working solution of natural pH 8.7 possess the ability to generate a considerable amount of �OH as described in Eq. (5) resulting in the maximum photodegradation rate (Sayed et al., 2017).
hþvb þ OH → �OH (5)

sections.heading: 3.11. Photocatalyst stability and reusability studies
sections.text:
The photostability of the biogenic developed defective ZnO NPs was examined via a cycling degradation testing. Fig. 14 illustrates the reusability of 4MSCDZnO for four degradation cycles of FL. As displayed, the photodegradation efficiency of FL slightly reduced upon the progress in recycling times. After four times reusing 4MSCDZnO catalyst in photodegradation of FL, about 89.1% of FL was photodegraded corresponding to an estimated degradation efficiency of 97.6% for the fresh
A.A. Essawy et al.
Journal of Environmental Management 271 (2020) 110961
photocatalyst used in the first cycle. In order for addressing reproducibility, three conducted repetitions are employed within a satisfactory standard deviation estimates. These results reflect considerable photostability and steadily photocatalytic performance for the developed biogenic ZnO NPs.

sections.heading: 3.12. Charge carriers trapping study
sections.text: Trapping of the electrons (e–) and holes (hþ) charge carriers is widely used to verify their functionality in the process of photodegradation. Scavenging electrons and holes was carried out by using tert-butyl alcohol and ammonium oxalate, respectively. As displayed in Fig. 15, addition of e– or hþ scavengers to the photodegradation suite noticeably reduce the degradation efficiency from 97.6% to 72.1% and 20.4%, respectively. Otherwise, the declination of degradation efficiency by 77.2% when using hþ scavenger compared to 25.5% in case of e– scavenger infers the strong contribution of holes in photodegradation reaction over the minor role of photoexcited electrons.

sections.heading: 3.13. Proposed degradation mechanism of FL by the biogenic synthesized ZnO defective NPs
sections.text:
Before giving an insight for the photocatalytic mechanism and the influence of illuminating the biogenic synthesized ZnO defective NPs by Solar photons, the empirical Eqs. (6) and (7) was used to assess the edge positions of valence and conduction bands (Balu et al., 2018):
EVB ¼ X – Eo þ 0.5Eg (6)
ECB ¼ EVB - Eg (7)
where EVB is the valence band energy, X represents the semiconductors’ absolute electronegativity, Eo is the energy of free electrons on basis of hydrogen scale (4.5 eV), Eg is the semiconductor band gap. The EVB and ECB for the biogenic synthesized ZnO defective NPs give an estimates of þ0.285 and 2.785 eV, respectively (Fig. 16). Meanwhile, with the aid of defective sites addressed along the developed biogenic synthesized ZnO NPs, a narrowing in band gab and improved absorption of Solar photons have been arisen.
Based on the aforementioned analyses, the illustrative scheme in Fig. 16 shows the influence of Solar photons in activating the biogenic synthesized ZnO defective NPs, generating the charge carriers holes (hþ) and electrons (e ). The holes can react with H2O creating the active oxidizing species, �OH. Meanwhile, the excited electrons to the conduction band can diffuse to the crystal defects thereby promoting their separation from holes (Karthik et al., 2018). These electrons can react with the O2 possibly adsorbed in the porous structure of defective ZnO producing the superoxide radical anions (�O2 ). The generated �OH and �O2 oxidizing species act their role in decomposing FL.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In the present work, a facile one pot green and sustainable synthetic route is successfully employed to prepare ZnO NPs using pomegranate seeds extract as a biogenic reducing and capping fuel during a novel solution combustion process. The biosynthesized ZnO in comparison
A.A. Essawy et al.
Journal of Environmental Management 271 (2020) 110961
with the bulky one prepared in absence of the biogenic reagent is of better response and narrowed band gab to absorb visible photons of solar light. Also, the biosynthesized ZnO is characterized by a nanoporous oxygen vacancies defective morphological sites in addition to smaller particle size, greater pore size/volume and higher surface area. These interesting features enables the biosynthesized ZnO NPs to efficiently produce relatively separable photogenerated charge carriers (electrons and holes). Thereafter produce higher density (�10 times higher) of hydroxyl radicals (�OH), the mostly active oxidative species involved in photodegradation of environmentally hazardous materials. Even further, examining the photocatalytic activity of the developed catalysts in degrading flumequine (FL) antibiotic illustrate the superior activity of the biogenic synthesized ZnO by 7.22 times over the bulk ZnO and 1.72 times greater than using commercial ZnO. Moreover, following the effect of pH on the photocatalytic degradability of FL results in remarkable retardation in the degradation rate at highly acidic or basic medium as attributed to the least contact of FL antibiotic pollutant and ZnO surface because of electrostatic repulsion between FL molecules and photocatalyst surface. Reusability test reflects considerable photostability and steadily photocatalytic performance of the biosynthesized ZnO NPs in degrading FL. Trapping of charge carriers infers the strong contribution of holes in photodegradation reaction over the minor role of photoexcited electrons. Therefore, the aforementioned findings are promising and pave the way to extensively use biogenic synthetic route to produce semiconductor NPs of tuned size and controlled morphology relevant to environmental remediation applications.

referenceMentions.context: Zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles were described among the various semiconductors as functionally promising and versatile inorganic materials with unparalleled optical and electrical properties that can be adjusted by modifying the size and morphology (Ma et al., 2019).

Accordingly, ZnO displays a wide variety of appealing applications in the optoelectronics, piezoelectrical devices, transparent electronics, chemical sensors (Saito et al., 2018; Zou et al., 2018; Li et al., 2018), environmental protection, pharmaceutical, cosmetic, agricultural and food industries (Espitia et al.

Accordingly, ZnO displays a wide variety of appealing applications in the optoelectronics, piezoelectrical devices, transparent electronics, chemical sensors (Saito et al., 2018; Zou et al., 2018; Li et al., 2018), environmental protection, pharmaceutical, cosmetic, agricultural and food industries (Espitia et al.

In addition, ZnO NPs demonstrated tremendous efficacy in biological and medical areas such as biological labeling, bio-sensing, gene delivery, drug delivery, nanomedicine and cosmetic sectors owing to their anti-microbial, anti-diabetic and wound healing capabilities (Dastjerdi and Montazer, 2010; Radzimska and Jesionowski, 2014; Mishra et al., 2017; Moezzi et al., 2012).

In addition, ZnO NPs demonstrated tremendous efficacy in biological and medical areas such as biological labeling, bio-sensing, gene delivery, drug delivery, nanomedicine and cosmetic sectors owing to their anti-microbial, anti-diabetic and wound healing capabilities (Dastjerdi and Montazer, 2010; Radzimska and Jesionowski, 2014; Mishra et al., 2017; Moezzi et al., 2012).

In addition, ZnO NPs demonstrated tremendous efficacy in biological and medical areas such as biological labeling, bio-sensing, gene delivery, drug delivery, nanomedicine and cosmetic sectors owing to their anti-microbial, anti-diabetic and wound healing capabilities (Dastjerdi and Montazer, 2010; Radzimska and Jesionowski, 2014; Mishra et al., 2017; Moezzi et al., 2012).
ZnO nanoparticles have a wurtzite structure and belong to the family of semiconductors category II-IV, which has a covalence between ionic and covalent semiconductors (Ngoepe et al., 2018).

(5) resulting in the maximum photodegradation rate (Sayed et al., 2017).
Meanwhile, the excited electrons to the conduction band can diffuse to the crystal defects thereby promoting their separation from holes (Karthik et al., 2018).

metadata.abstractText: Herein, novel green/facile approach to synthesize spongy defective zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnONPs) is presented using for the first time pomegranate seeds molasses as a green capping fuel/reducing mediator during an aqueous solution combustion process. The developed ZnONPs is characterized by UV–Vis. Spectrophotometry and fluorimetry, XRD, Raman spectroscopy, SEM, TEM and BET. Interestingly, pomegranate seeds molasses within a viable content of bio-capping molecules reveal a defective nanoporous ZnO NPs of smaller particle size, greater pore size/volume, and higher surface area compared to the bulky non-biogenic ZnONPs. Moreover, the biosynthesized defective ZnONPs showed narrowed band gap and higher absorption of visible photons that breed higher density of hydroxyl radicals (OH) under Solar-illumination. Even further, the bulk ZnO and the biosynthesized ZnO photocatalysts were examined in photodegrading flumequine (FL) antibiotic. The bulk ZnO gives 41.46% photodegradation efficiency compared to 97.6% for the biosynthesized ZnO. In highly acidic or highly alkaline media, FL photodegradability is greatly retarded. Scavenging experiment infers considerable contribution of holes over electrons in photodegradation reaction. The biosynthesized ZnO shows high durability in FL photodegradation after four reusing cycles. These promising findings highlight new insights for biogenic synthesis of tuned size/controlled morphology semiconductor NPs relevant to environmental remediation
metadata.creator: Elsevier
